Issues.Title: Zone.js standardization track push
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

### Tl;dr;

I would like to see a push for Zone.js to be brought into the standards track with TC39, or at least Async context tracking (similar to node.js async hooks). I'm using Zone.js in production code to track async context variables, and we'll be in a bind if we lose this ability.

Can we push to get Zone.js standardized again, or at least something that would allow us to save state in the async execution context?

# Backstory

In our organization, we have a concept called "Flows". It's similar to ngrx actions, but they are more like a function with a declared return type. I tell new employees they can think about it like a C header file, that gets linked at runtime; It uses the Angular dependency injector under the hood to abstract away a lot of configuration snafus.

We use flows for a lot of things, including navigation between sections of our app. A real world example is the "Go To Dashboard" function - each user depending on their individual attributes might have a different dashboard. This is complicated further by our large list of clients. Each of our clients can reconfigure their instance to change what "Dashboard" means for their organization. Sometimes, these dashboards are a 3rd URL that is _not_ controlled by Angular, or at least not the same Angular app.

Using a "flow", we can easily abstract away the implementation details of figuring out _which_ dashboard should be rendered, and how to get there. All navigation links can then just invoke the flow, eventually navigating the user.

While this can be invoked with a (click) callback, I like anchor tags, and would like to use these same flows to determine a static href, not just navigate. Simple enough; I can just flip the switch on the navigation engine we use to "record" rather than actually navigate there.

The problem comes down to `async`. Because the same flow could be triggered programmatically (in which case we want to actually navigate there) at the same time the href determination service is running, I need a way to know the execution context at the time the function is executing.

Zone.js works great for this! Since I can just fork the zone before executing, I can know whether or not the current callback should be _executing_ or _recording_. I use WeakMaps to track settings per zone, using Zone.current to look up the appropriate behavior inside the callback.

## My probelm

If Angular moves to a Zoneless future (because of native async / await), I will lose a major part of my capabilities, and have to maintain two separate execution paths for href links, vs button links.

Are there any other ways to resolve this, without Zone.js? How can we track async execution context without it?

### Proposed solution

I could live without Zone.js but it would require two separate codepaths any time you needed something you could previously sandbox with Zone.

### Alternatives considered

I don't think we have any alternatives unless async context tracking is standardized.

Issues.Title: Recent change in compiler-cli breaks jest-preset-angular
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler-cli

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

I'm currently investigating an error that occurs in certain situations when running tests with jest-preset-angular and typescript 4.8. There are several issue reports over at jest-preset-angular, nrwl/nx and possibly others.

### Error description

In short, this code will break jest / jest-preset-angular, throwing `ReferenceError: anywhere_1 is not defined`, when running typescript 4.8.

```ts
import {InterfaceFromInterfaceOnlyModule } from './anywhere' ;
class X {
	@MyDecorator() test():InterfaceFromInterfaceOnlyModule { ... }
}
```

A reproduction is available at https://github.com/jbjhjm/jest28-bug .

The error occurs when following circumstances are given:

- use angular with typescript 4.8 (so ng 15) and jest with jest-preset-angular
- Import nothing but an interface or type from a module
- Use it on a method that is being decorated
- Have emitDecoratorMetadata enabled

It seems like response type of a decorated method somehow "bleeds" into compiled javascript, where it causes an error because the type-only module does not exist anymore, ending up in a ReferenceError.

### Origin of error

jest-preset-angular uses the downlevel_decorators_transform.ts from compiler-cli.
We managed to hunt the error down to a recent change in there.

https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/47167 modified that file in L565, replacing updateClassDeclaration by  createClassDeclaration. 

Here https://github.com/thymikee/jest-preset-angular/issues/1199#issuecomment-1345445251 , @n9niwas has shown a patch reverting that change to make it work as desired again, stating: "Idk for sure, but suspect that calling create* methods instead of update* makes TS program to forget information about whether a particular import is type-only or not."

@crisbeto , your insights might help here a lot.
I am not sure if downlevel_decorators_transform currently generates unexpected code, or if jest-preset-angular needs to update its own implementation to work correctly with the new code.
What's your estimation? Can you explain why `createClassDeclaration` is used now?

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler): refactor the shadow css specs
Issues.Body:
apply different quality of life improvements to the shadow css unit tests:

- refactor the tests so that they are nicely divided in multiple files in a logical manner instead of having most of them all in a single big file

- remove the css normalization logic inconsistently used throughout the tests, which caused tests to be inconsistent and it also introduced unintuitive checks

- provide a shared shim utility function (instead of re-defining it multiple times)

- add a `toCssEqual` matcher that can be used in the tests in order to match css strings without caring about spacing and indentation

- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## The refactoring

As I mentioned in the commit I felt like the shadow css specs could use a bit of a clean up so I went for it (I hope you'll find the refactoring beneficial :slightly_smiling_face: )

To break down the points I made in the commit:

> - refactor the tests so that they are nicely divided in multiple files in a logical manner instead of having most of them all in a single big file

as you can see the [shadow_css_spec.ts](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/b5bb4c17d02cc226343487476f065c0f6535edae/packages/compiler/test/shadow_css/shadow_css_spec.ts) file is 586 lines long and I believe that splitting it up can help in making things more clear and convenient.

> - remove the css normalization logic inconsistently used throughout the tests, which causes tests to be inconsistent and it also introduced unintuitive checks

regarding the normalization I wanted to remove it because it was making things quite inconsistent and confusing I believe, some tests were relying on it and some didn't and the name "normalization" and why it is necessary just felt very unintuitive to me, for example this is one of the effect it caused:
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/b5bb4c17d02cc226343487476f065c0f6535edae/packages/compiler/test/shadow_css/shadow_css_spec.ts#L176
as you can see in the expected value the `b` is wrapped by double quotes, that doesn't come from the shim itself but from the extra normalization added on top of it... I think this just makes thing less clear and I am not sure what the benefit of it is (I may be wrong, please correct me if I am :slightly_smiling_face:)

> - provide a shared shim utility function (instead of re-defining it multiple times)

as you can see in the three existing spec files we are more or less re-creating the same function:
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/b5bb4c17d02cc226343487476f065c0f6535edae/packages/compiler/test/shadow_css/container_queries_spec.ts#L12-L15
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/b5bb4c17d02cc226343487476f065c0f6535edae/packages/compiler/test/shadow_css/keyframes_spec.ts#L12-L15
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/b5bb4c17d02cc226343487476f065c0f6535edae/packages/compiler/test/shadow_css/shadow_css_spec.ts#L14-L18

> - add a `toCssEqual` matcher that can be used in the tests in order to match css strings without caring about spacing and indentation

with this we can avoid that confusing normalization logic and also not having to rely on the [noIndentation](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/b5bb4c17d02cc226343487476f065c0f6535edae/packages/compiler/test/shadow_css/container_queries_spec.ts#L53-L55) utility function. doing `expect(...).toCssEqual` feels much cleaner to me.

(By the way, in the PR I mostly moved tests around, I just simply added/removed utilities around that as well, no tests have been removed or added)

Issues.Title: Ng class perf one map
Issues.Body:
Notice: still in draft for G3 testing (!!!)

This commit represents rewrite of the NgClass directive to address
severe performance problem (excessive DOM mutation). The modified
algorithm removes all the known performance clifs and has number of
desirable properties:
- it is shorter and (arguably) easier to follow;
- drops usage of existing differs thus limiting dependencies on other
part of the code without increasing size of the directive;
- doesn't degrade any other performance metrics.

### algorithm notes

The NgClass directive uses the custom change detection algorithm for its inputs. The custom
  algorithm is necessary since inputs are represented as complex object or arrays that need to be
  deeply-compared.

  This algorithm is perf-sensitive since NgClass is used very frequently and its poor performance
  might negatively impact runtime performance of the entire change detection cycle. The design of
  this algorithm is making sure that:
  - there is no unnecessary DOM manipulation (CSS classes are added / removed from the DOM only when
  needed), even if references to bound objects change;
  - there is no memory allocation if nothing changes (even relatively modest memory allocation
  during the change detection cycle can result in GC pauses for some of the CD cycles).

  The algorithm works by iterating over the set of bound classes, staring with [class] binding and
  then going over [ngClass] binding. For each CSS class name:
  - check if it was seen before (this information is tracked in the state map) and if its value
  changed;
  - mark it as "touched" - names that are not marked are not present in the latest set of binding
  and we can remove such class name from the internal data structures;

  Please note that we track "changed" state in a particular way (by using % 2 counter): this is done
  so 2 changes that cancel each other out (ex. `<[class]="'foo'" [ngClass]="{foo: false}"`) don't
  result in any DOM manipulation.

  After iteration over all the CSS class names we've got data structure with all the information
  necessary to synchronize changes to the DOM - it is enough to iterate over the state map, flush
  changes to the DOM and reset internal data structures so those are ready for the next change
  detection cycle.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): only set ngDevMode when script optimizations are enabled
Issues.Body: When using the experimental esbuild-based browser application builder, the `ngDevMode` global runtime variable was unintentionally always being set to false due to a previous bug fix that stopped the variable from being replaced with the value of true when script optimizations were disabled. By doing so, the fix caused the imported compiler-cli `GLOBAL_DEFS_FOR_TERSER_WITH_AOT` constant to take precedence which contains an `ngDevMode` value of false. To prevent this situation for development builds where a non-false `ngDevMode` is helpful to surface potential runtime problems, `GLOBAL_DEFS_FOR_TERSER_WITH_AOT` will no longer change the value of `ngDevMode`. This fix does not have any effect on production builds since `ngDevMode` would have been set to false regardless.

    Version 0.16.0 of esbuild moved esbuild's binary executables into npm packages under the `@esbuild/` scope, which accidentally broke the binary downloader script for Deno. This release fixes this script so it should now be possible to use esbuild version 0.16.4+ with Deno.

In that case the parent node process was still waiting for the esbuild process that was created by the child node process to exit. The change made in version 0.15.13 was trying to avoid using Go's `sync.WaitGroup` API incorrectly because the API is not thread-safe. Issues.Title: Allow extending generated webpack config of karma builder
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#-commit-message-guidelines
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

## PR Type

What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the current behavior?

The `@angular-devkit/build-angular:karma` builder generates a webpack configuration, and runs webpack (and karma) with that configuration. Currently that configuration cannot be changed by the user, even if the user provides a webpack configuration in their karma config.

## What is the new behavior?

The user's webpack configuration is merged together with the generated configuration, using `webpack-merge`.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

## Other information

This was previously possible, but the commit 04f5dfe5e2fc97bcf0641f1d2f8edfc59dae57b2 replaced  `Object.assign(webpackConfig, config.webpack)` with a spread operator, which means that `webpackConfig` was not changed anymore.

Since the generated configuration uses functions (and the user's configuration could as well), `webpack-merge` is used to merge the configurations. Since `webpack-merge` will throw an error when passing undefined values, the code first checks that a value to-be-merged exists.

Issues.Title: bug(v15 Schematics): Schematics are targeting new MDC prebuilt theme instead of legacy prebuilt theme
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The schematics behind `ng update @angular/material --next` are changing the imports to the legacy components as intended BUT in `angular.json` the imports for the prebuilt theme are not updated from **`@angular/material/prebuilt-themes/indigo-pink.css`** to **`@angular/material/legacy-prebuilt-themes/legacy-indigo-pink.css`**. This obviously means that the legacy components are attempted to be rendered using the styles for the new MDC components which results in a broken UI.

With that being said I can't figure out how to incrementally migrate to the new MDC components. The legacy prebuilt theme styles are needed to have the legacy components working properly but in order to migrate one component to its MDC counterpart the styles for the MDC prebuilt theme have to be loaded and both themes can't be used at the same time.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Update an Angular 14 app to Angular 15 while keeping Angular Material 14. (works without issues as far as I can tell)
`"dependencies": {
    "@angular/animations": "^15.0.0",
    **"@angular/cdk": "^14.2.0",**
    "@angular/common": "^15.0.0",
    "@angular/compiler": "^15.0.0",
    "@angular/core": "^15.0.0",
    "@angular/forms": "^15.0.0",
    **"@angular/material": "^14.2.0",**
    "@angular/platform-browser": "^15.0.0",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "^15.0.0",
    "@angular/router": "^15.0.0",
    "rxjs": "~7.5.0",
    "tslib": "^2.3.0",
    "zone.js": "~0.12.0"
  },`
2. Run `ng update @angular/material --next` to upgrade to Angular Material 15.
3. Run the app. At this point the UI will be broken.


### Expected Behavior

In `angular.json` the imports for the prebuilt theme should be updated to **`@angular/material/legacy-prebuilt-themes/legacy-indigo-pink.css`** to have working legacy components.

### Actual Behavior

In `angular.json` the imports for the prebuilt theme **ARE NOT** updated to **`@angular/material/legacy-prebuilt-themes/legacy-indigo-pink.css`** which leads to broken legacy components (from styling point of view).

### Environment

- Angular: 15
- CDK/Material: 14 (attempting update to 15)
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System: Windows 10
